question: Describe the client-server model in detail and explain how sockets enable communication between processes across a network. Include practical examples of how socket programming is used.
Compare TCP and UDP protocols in terms of reliability, connection handling, and use-cases. Discuss scenarios where one is preferred over the other and justify your reasoning.
Explain the structure and purpose of an IPv4 datagram. Describe how fragmentation and reassembly work during packet transmission across networks.
Compare the OSI and TCP/IP network models by describing each layer's role and mapping functions between the two models. Highlight their significance in protocol design.
Describe the responsibilities of each layer in the OSI model. For each layer, provide a practical example of a protocol and explain its function in the communication process.
Explain how HTTP operates as a stateless application-layer protocol. Discuss the structure of HTTP requests and responses, including the roles of headers and status codes.
Define protocol ports and explain their role in identifying specific processes on a host. Provide examples of well-known port numbers and the services that use them.
Describe how email systems use SMTP, POP3, IMAP, and HTTP to send, retrieve, and display messages. Highlight the differences in functionality between these protocols.
Discuss the concept of reliable data transfer in networking. Describe how TCP ensures reliability through error detection, acknowledgments, and retransmission.
Define congestion control and flow control in the context of transport protocols. Explain how TCP implements both mechanisms and why they are essential for performance.
Explain how processes in distributed systems communicate using IP addresses and port numbers. Describe the significance of each in socket-based networking.
Describe the role of a router in a network. List its main components and explain how they work together to forward packets between networks.
Compare distance-vector and link-state routing algorithms. Discuss their mechanisms, convergence behavior, and which is more scalable in large networks.
What are multiplexing and demultiplexing in transport-layer services? Describe how port numbers and headers facilitate these functions with examples.
Explain the key differences between IPv4 and IPv6 in terms of address format, header structure, and additional features. What are the benefits of adopting IPv6?
Discuss the purpose of acknowledgments and sequence numbers in TCP. Explain how they support ordered, reliable data delivery and loss detection.
Define process scheduling in operating systems. Describe the types of queues and schedulers used in managing process execution and system performance.
Explain peer-to-peer (P2P) networking. Compare it with the client-server model, and discuss the benefits and challenges of P2P architectures.
Describe the core transport-layer services such as flow control, error control, and multiplexing/demultiplexing. Explain how these services support communication between applications.
Describe typical message exchange patterns in distributed systems, such as request-response and publish-subscribe. Use an example to illustrate the flow of communication.
Explain the structure and purpose of HTTP headers in a web communication. Describe common header fields such as Host, User-Agent, Content-Type, and how they affect client-server interaction.
Discuss how the transport layer ensures end-to-end communication between applications. Explain the interaction between the application layer and transport layer during data transmission.
